text: For more hardening you could also consider using a KMS <https://docs.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_security.html#security-hardening>

elements.text: For more hardening you could also consider using a KMS

text: <@U09AQULJPQ8> Well the whole idea of a secure cryptographic secret key is that you can't easily derive it from something else :slightly_smiling_face: If you have truly lost it than you are in the same position as an adversary trying to steal your coins. So this is a feature.

elements.text: Well the whole idea of a secure cryptographic secret key is that you can't easily derive it from something else
If you have truly lost it than you are in the same position as an adversary trying to steal your coins. So this is a feature.

text: Could you perhaps open a fresh thread with your precise query? Trying to get the right context out of the long thread above will likely lead to misunderstandings.

text:
And s.a. <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#disaster-recovery> - maybe the answer is there! For example

> If a full backup is unavailable but an identity backup has been created, the balance of the validator can be recovered on a new validator.
If neither a database backup is available nor an identities backup, and you are also not using an external KMS (you probably are not) - your keys are lost and with them access to all the assets tied to them.

elements.text: And s.a.
- maybe the answer is there! For example
If a full backup is unavailable but an identity backup has been created, the balance of the validator can be recovered on a new validator.

If neither a database backup is available nor an identities backup, and you are also not using an external KMS (you probably are not) - your keys are lost and with them access to all the assets tied to them.

text:
Hi Martin :grinning: 
Random question re your last message in this thread (thread about everything at once).
Does <https://docs.dev.sync.global/validator_operator/validator_disaster_recovery.html#restoring-a-validator-from-backups|this> work if the node was last active 2+ months ago and at that time we had a different migration ID active on the network?

elements.text: Hi Martin

Random question re your last message in this thread (thread about everything at once).
Does
this
work if the node was last active 2+ months ago and at that time we had a different migration ID active on the network?

text:
• if your node was not active for longer than the sequencer pruning retention period (30 days) then it can't catch up anymore and the backups won't help you
• if your node missed a hard migration and only comes up after the SVs took down their legacy synchronizer nodes, then it can't catch up on the old synchronizer, can't complete the migration, and the backups won't help you
So if only one of these happens, you need to recover from key.

Will try to get to expanding the docs today to better cover both your and <@U09AQULJPQ8>'s questions.

elements.text: if your node was not active for longer than the sequencer pruning retention period (30 days) then it can't catch up anymore and the backups won't help you

if your node missed a hard migration and only comes up after the SVs took down their legacy synchronizer nodes, then it can't catch up on the old synchronizer, can't complete the migration, and the backups won't help you

So if only one of these happens, you need to recover from key.

Will try to get to expanding the docs today to better cover both your and
's questions.

text:
Hi!
We are trying to change the validator's partyHint by editing 'validator*PartyHint' value in the helm chart*, but encountered an error described in the troubleshooting guide <https://docs.sync.global/deployment/troubleshooting.html#node-has-identity-x-but-identifier-y-was-expected>

We are running the validator for ~3 months on devnet, so we can't drop the database. We didn't find any method in the documentation to meet our goal, which is replacing the current validator's partyHint with the new one. We are doing all this to move the validator to a different IP address.

I guess we'll have to replace the 'nodeIdentifier' as well.

1. What are the proper steps to change partyHint?
2. Would we need to change nodeIdentifier too?
3. Is there any documentation describing the process?
Looking forward to any advice.

elements.text:
Hi!
We are trying to change the validator's partyHint by editing 'validator
PartyHint' value in the helm chart
, but encountered an error described in the troubleshooting guide

We are running the validator for ~3 months on devnet, so we can't drop the database. We didn't find any method in the documentation to meet our goal, which is replacing the current validator's partyHint with the new one. We are doing all this to move the validator to a different IP address.

I guess we'll have to replace the 'nodeIdentifier' as well.
What are the proper steps to change partyHint?
Would we need to change nodeIdentifier too?
Is there any documentation describing the process?
Looking forward to any advice.

text: It is not possible to change the party hint

elements.text: It is not possible to change the party hint

text: I think it’s possible, you just need to clear cleanup your database and do a fresh new validator. If it’s ONLY devnet then who cares about the tokens. On test and main -> you can’t change.

elements.text: I think it’s possible, you just need to clear cleanup your database and do a fresh new validator. If it’s ONLY devnet then who cares about the tokens. On test and main -> you can’t change.
